title: Resource Attributes
description:
Not every resource of a given type is identical. Customers differ in profitability, staff differ in experience, and so on. Few resources are uniform such as cash.  Each dollar bill is the same as all the others. Most resources, however, vary in important ways:

  • Customers may be larger or smaller, highly profitable or not.
  • Products may appeal to many customers or a few, and satisfy some, many, or all of their needs.
  • Staff may have more experience or less, and cost high salaries or low.

A resource attribute is a characteristic that varies between different items in a singular pool of resources. Attributes may be potential rather than actual and may still require efforts on our part if they are to be developed. For example, opening a new retail store brings access to the population around that store. Those potential customers will only become actual customers if the stores provide attractive products, prices, and service.

However, it is important to focus on the correct attribute for the intended purpose. Customer revenue is a useful measure but may not necessarily correspond to customer profitability. One may need to think more widely for deciding which attributes are important, apart from revenue and profit contribution. For example, a majority of the banks is engaged in a competitive pursuit of individuals with high net worth. These customers have large potential deposits as well as borrowing needs on which a bank can make a good margin. They are, however, the best informed and least loyal of customers, often following the best deals from bank to bank. Far from being the most valuable customers, they can rather be the most costly to serve.

It is to be noted that it may be possible to do a profitable business serving customers that, for other companies, are unattractive. For example, the large information technology (IT) service providers such as Infosys, EDS, and CSC would not be interested in a moment in serving small business clients, but there is a prospective market for small computer support service providers among those same small clients. 

If we are to add a clear picture of resource attributes to the strategic architecture, we need to capture their dynamics accurately. Three mechanisms cause attribute levels to change:-

  1. Directly increasing the attribute without making any change to the tangible resource. For example, banks may win a larger share from existing customers by getting more of their savings/borrowing requirements.
  2. Obtaining new or better quality resources with more of the desired attribute.
    This raises the average quality of the total resource pool. On the other hand, bringing in poorer quality resources disturbs the average quality.
  3. Losing the resources that have too little of the desired attribute.
    This raises the average quality of those which remain. For example, dropping unprofitable customers or discontinuing unpopular products.

title: Child’s Play- Managing Competitive Dynamics
description:
Building our own resources is challenging enough, but competitors are not going to sit by and let you take whatever we want without a fight. Even in a nonbusiness situation, we struggle to win people, cash, supporters, and other resources. 

A majority of the population think about rivalry in the context of competitive markets for goods and services. Discussions of competitiveness often focus on high-level measures such as sales growth, market share, etc. However, these are not factors which can have any direct effect but are the results of success in winning, developing, and retaining important resources.

Since most of what we know about rivalry comes from the knowledge of price- and value-based markets, it is perhaps not surprising that the customer markets grab all the attention. This focus has the most unfortunate consequence. The competitive strategy seems to have little relevance to nonprofit sectors such as public services, the voluntary sector, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). Yet these organizations constantly compete for resources. Skilled staff is an obvious example, but supporters, cash, and other resources must also be battled for.

Nevertheless, customers are still the most obvious resource that must be won and retained against rivals, so this is where the focus is needed most. However, most of the principles are readily applicable to the rivalry for staff and other resources as well.

As new potential customers develop, rivals fight to win them to maximize profitability. They also seek to develop a potential pool of resources. The challenge for organizations, with developing potential customers, is to understand what is driving the customers’ choice. Their choices will be driven by the competitors’ decisions and actions, especially:-

  • sales and marketing activities
  • relative prices
  • relatively perceived outcome of competing products.

Many markets feature a group of hard-to-persuade customers who often fail to move despite strong inducements, either because of emotional reasons, such as loyalty or comfort or because of simple inertia. The deregulation of utility markets was supposed to encourage the mass migration of customers from inefficient incumbent suppliers to many new entrants who would offer competitive prices. In practice, many customers fail to switch in spite of the prospect of considerable savings.

This type of rivalry increases in importance as markets develop. Firms fight to pull customers out of their rivals’ resource systems and into their own, so the more customers are in that state, the more intense rivalry becomes. Customers benefit from a range of incentives to stay or join, which is why the regulatory competition policies focus strongly on eliminating switching costs.

title: Intangibles
description:
Soft factors play a major role in competitive performance. A motivated staff is more productive than those with poor morale, a strong reputation in the market helps customer acquisition, a charity that enjoys its donors’ commitment will raise money more easily, and a political party with a stronger support among the electorate will get more votes. If we are to improve performance over time, then we have no other choice but to understand how to assess and influence those soft factors.

The performance at each moment depends on the tangible resources we can access. The only way to change the performance is by building and sustaining these resources. So, if soft factors are to make any difference to performance, they must do so by affecting our firm’s ability to capture and hold on to the same tangible resources.

Unfortunately, intangible resources can be tough to manage. We may easily borrow cash, buy production capacity, or hire staff, but it is slow and difficult to build a strong reputation, staff morale or support from our donors or voters.

Once you have a strong intangible, it will automatically speed up the growth of other resources. Imagine the likely performance advantage for an organization with an edge in all these factors. Since it is often hard for competitors to see from outside what these intangibles exactly are and to work out how to collect them, they can give us as a sustainable advantage.

In a company, the atmosphere where people are confident and motivated feels quite different from that in an organization where staff is under pressure. Similarly, salespeople know the difference in a customer’s reaction when they try to sell products with a bad reputation, and CEOs notice the hostility of investors who have lost confidence in their management.

Organizations increasingly measure intangible factors like product and service quality, staff skills, and motivation. Even investor sentiment is periodically tracked and scrutinized by various companies. The achievements of exemplary managers in difficult situations make it clear that the intangibles are manageable. Effective factory managers can improve product quality, inspirational managers can boost the sales force morale and confidence, and a capable chief executive can reassure anxious investors.

A clue that we are dealing with an intangible resource comes when the word perceived features in our likely explanation for what is going on. Perceived menu quality is the key. For example, a restaurant’s ability to win new customers because those people do not have any direct experience of what they will be served until they have really eaten there. The perceived appeal of working in the media industry is key to encouraging young people to seek a job with the media (radio and TV) companies. The perceived quality of management is a vital factor for entrepreneurs to win over investors. This is barely a new idea, the core principle in cognitive psychology is that the state of mind drives behavior.

title: Business ethics and advertisement: How do these concepts interrelate?
description:
In order to understand the relationship between business ethics and advertising, we need to give a deep insight into the role of advertising in the context of broader business operations. This is appropriate because business ethics is expressed and is evolved in the context of any business activity. Advertising is the most important part of these functions in terms of companies’ communication with the wider audience.

When creating a new company or expanding it by launching a new service or product, a business plan should implement that deals with the procedures that should be followed. A key element of this plan is the marketing mix that is dictated by the marketing strategy that has been shaped by market research, segmentation and targeting to potential consumers. The marketing strategy to be described as successful must serves the marketing ideology apart from being technically perfect.

The marketing ideology, in turn, is summarized in the following principles: 

·        It is based on intense,continuous and unrestricted business orientation towards the buyer

·        It recognizes that the buyer is the only one who knows what to satisfy

·        It recalls that the sole purpose of each business is to meet the buyer's needs,from which the company will generate profits. This satisfaction will be achieved by accurately delivering theproduct specification requirements.This ideology must serve without provoking and offending the common sense of ethics that governs the average consumer

The marketing mix consists of four elements, one of which is the promotion. Advertising is the mean by which the enterprise is addressed to the wider community regardless of whether it is made up of potential buyers or not. Therefore, advertising is the way in which business ethics, as embodied in all of the company's operations, is expressed and communicated to the public

At this point, it raises two key questions: First, to what extent advertising reflects the business ethics? Is it able to make consumers understand how the business operates in the whole range of its activities, eg, labor relations, economic policy, and administrative decisions? Secondly, can the image of the business, from an ethical point of view be altered to presentan idealized advertising?

To answer the first question, we can say that the advertising campaigns clearly cannot give a complete picture of the companies’ ethics. Butthere are aspects of the business that can be seen in advertising. In principle, consumers can see whether the business respects them or not. For example, if the advertising message is particularly challenging or if it tries to "rape" its value system by identifying products with socialrecognition, it is an indication that the business does not follow some moral limits.

Also, in some cases, consumers viewing an advertisement may understand the way that businesses deal with various issues, such as environment, minority groups, and global unemployment. Concerning the second the issue, namely the deterioration of the actual code of ethicsthat exists, so that consumers have a good image of the business, we can accept that it ispartly true. Empirically evidence shows that after a while,the majority of consumers understand the fraud on the part of the business and turns as boomerang damaging its brand image

Consumers’ maturity, increased critical capacity, level of education, level of information, and willingness to deal with relevant issues,play a particularly important role in the ethics of advertising. At present, consumers have, on average, satisfactory levels of literacy, judgment, and maturity. This translates into the fact that businesses need to be very careful and not try to deceive consumers about their ethics by using advertising So, nowadays, consumers have the opportunity to see the true motives behind companies’ advertising and hence businesses are forced to revise their own incentives to be moral if firms want to maintain their competitive advantages!

title: Capability Building and Resource Development
description:
Capabilities are powerful drivers of performance for businesses and various other kinds of organizations. They are the factors which determine how well groups achieve tasks that are critical. For our strategic architecture of resources, one of the most critical tasks is building and retaining resources. Capabilities differ from resources in the following way:-

  • Resources are useful items that we own or can access.
  • Capabilities are activities that our organization is good at performing.

Capabilities are important because they determine how effectively our organization builds, develops, and retains resources. A more capable organization will be able to build resources faster and hold resource losses at a slower rate than a less capable organization. Capabilities, like intangible resources, are ambiguous items that are difficult to measure and manage. Nevertheless, they are important drivers of performance over a period of time, so attempts must be made to understand and manage them.

A team’s capability is the ratio between the rate at which it actually achieves tasks and the best rate that we can imagine. Never confuse team capabilities with individual skills. 

Clever organizations manage to hire relatively unskilled people and generate outstanding performance. Consulting firms take newly trained professionals and enable them to deliver sophisticated business solutions. Fast-food firms take unskilled staff and produce highly consistent products, call centers take people with little understanding of the organization’s products and clients and manage to produce excellent customer support; and so on.

Clearly, these organizations achieve much of this performance by training people. In other words, by adding to individual skills. But they also develop, test, and operate proven procedures. Team capability reflects the combination of individual skills and these effective procedures.

Such procedures add up to a library of instructions for completing specific activities reliably and quickly. This library is an effective resource and like any resource, it is built up over time. It is also kept up to date by the removal of obsolete procedures and the addition of new ones. 

Team capabilities are built up by being utilized, much as individual skills are. Procedures for getting things done are available to be recorded whenever they take place. Clearly the more chances the team has to practice its developing and retention of resources, the more opportunities arise to improve and record the procedures that work best. 

The bottom line is that the rate of resource flow determines the rate at which capabilities can be improved. There are some cases where capability does not directly relate to a specific resource flow, but they tend to be less influential on long-term strategic performance than are these tightly coupled pairing of resource and capability.

title: Intuition with business
description:
"Business with a well tuned sixth sense makes it a perfect go"

Dealing with business or anything that you are doing for past years will eventually develop an intuition within you everytime you are going to make a new move. It's not about business but everywhere. Business owner gradually develops an intuition or call it a sixth sense which is hugely valuable for helping to make better decisions about everything we do in business.

But the problems arise when we become too busy in hearing what our intuition says or trying to say. We intellectualize because we are so bombarded with the information that e simply can't hear our intuition in midst of the clutter. But we can learn to see and hear our intuition to make a great change in our love when we make a deal.

1. Try to reconnect how you feel

Always look for the reality of a situation. There are many times your instinct will tell you not to do this in business but the brain will rationalize it in some different way and will give you something different. We just need to reconnect with how we feel at a deeper level with a free mind.

2. Learn from the right things in the past

Think about all the things you have done in the past and the think about all the right things you have done in the past. Feel good about those things and then get yourself some motivation. Try to reconnect with how you intuitively felt as they developing. That's the intuitive feeling we want to look for to give us the green light.

3. Have a checklist for all the decisions

Always have a checklist to help decide what things to do in a specific project. It will contain things like things which will interest you, is it profitable enough, do you have a skill etc. This will really help but most important to add to the checklist is "what my intuition says?". This has changed everything and makes difference. So take a project which shows actually blue ticks on your intuition message.

Intuition is not a new thing. We all know about it, we all have it but we don't use it. Intuition, sixth sense, instinct or call whatever you want to call but the more we listen to it, easier it becomes for us to have better decisions in our life. And, hence the quality of our decision will be reflected.

title: How to make a business plan
description:
Many people wonder how to start a business and make it work well.
Nonetheless, a specific recipe does not exist, but there are some directions that one can follow and set the right bases! Below we will simply try to show the great importance of "business planning" to the success of the business and we will see how entrepreneurs can start their own business plan.

To start a business, it needs innovative business ideas, a strong management team, and an appreciable capital.
When these are done then we have the business.
However, having the capital and making the business to operate effectively is something different. It requires knowledge, business planning, and vision.

In which questions a business plan should answer?

· Where is your business now?

· Which would you like to see your business in the future?

· How do you plan to get there?

These are the three basic questions where a business plan calls for answers whether you have a kind of business or are planning to open a company in the future.
In any case, the business plan should be a clear and comprehensible presentation of the goals and activities that the business is about to develop.

Also, some useful questions you can ask yourself are:

· Why do you think your business idea will be sustainable?

· What products and services do you sell?

· Why should you choose a consumer rather than your competitors?

· What else can you offer?

· What market needs do you plan to cover?

It should be noted that many businessmen do not have clear answers to these questions and this can prevent the company from developing and profiting.

 Drawing your business plan, you can make a description of your products by placing a special emphasis on how to use their customers.

What will be the benefit for the consumers if they purchase your product?

Also, it is imperative to show the reasons why your product will be successful on the market and continue with an analysis of the market you plan to operate by specifying the customers you address, and the profile of the consumer you are interested in making your customer, their habits, and income. What’s more, being aware of the competition that you may encounter is also very important for placing your business on the market. After doing an analysis of your products and services, customers and competitors, you can then describe who you would like to see your business after a few years, namely which is the vision that you have for the future and the personal lifestyle that you would like to live with. Finally, you should develop a strategy and set individual goals.

In the end, determine how you will reach the desired point in the future.
In this part, you should analyze the viability of the business according to the activities it is going to be developed.
All possible costs and revenues of the company should be calculated to allow proper planning for the achievement of the company's objectives. Cost calculations are made after you have taken into account the cost of setting up your business, the cost of purchasing equipment, operating expenses, staff salary costs, and working capital needed to start the business.
The company’s revenues need a careful estimation and are calculated on the basis of sales forecasts.
Sales forecasts are based on the calculation of the competitive advantages of your products, the size of the market you targets, the current competition and sales of past years, if your business is already operating, or sales of similar businesses if you are starting now.

I hope all the above steps not to seem to you as a "mountain". It's not something that should scare you.
It takes determination and self-discipline to complete it.
Think that the business plan you make will be the "bushel" in your business and does not need to be static.
If you want to change something you have all the freedom to do it!

title: A platform for Business
description:
We do remember the days having a cab driver's visiting card in all our purses so that we could go home on a rainy day by calling him before an hour we finish work, then wait for him to come, pick us up. We also remember the days when we know 2 or 3 restaurants that deliver food home so as to skip a day's cooking. But now it's all changed.

We book a cab, in minutes, it arrives and we go home. A million options to choose from while we sit at our desk ordering food. How does this all happen? Goods and services delivered through an app have made the world, even more, smaller, faster and lazier. 

These apps are widespread in all sectors. Allow me to give you examples.

Food sector - Swiggy, Zomato

Cabs             - Ola, Uber

E-commerce- Flipkart, Amazon

Services       - Practo, Tuner automobiles.

So how do these apps enjoy profits?

In the case of Swiggy, the app has provided a platform for restaurants and customers to order and deliver food. A certain amount of commission is given to the app for food ordered through the app i.e The app lets people know that such and such restaurant delivers food, a person orders through the app, so new customers are created for the restaurant and this service is turned into profit. Swiggy also gets paid for delivering food for restaurants that do not have a delivering facility.

In the case of Tuner automobiles, the app offers various car and bike services on the app. One can simply order for a car wash, select the nearest service station and get it done on spot. The platform provided is "encashed".

Several of these startups are now business giants but companies like Uber and food panda, with a lot of investment, are serious competition nevertheless.

title: The problem of data explosion
description:
The problem of data explosion is inherent to the complexity of the modern business market. This is because the development of the IT sector and especially the advent of Internet provoke a proliferation to the data and consequently to the information that companies receive. Particularly, companies understanding the great value that data put in the organizations’ development were prompted to collect and produce lots of data so as to ensure that they are fully aware oftheir operating activities and the market trends. 

Due to these practices, the data explosion appears. As data explosion can be defined as the phenomenon of which the sheer amount and the volume of data are becoming unmanageable for companies. The prime risk that entails the constant growth of data is that data become less structured; hence making difficult for executives to extract the proper information and acquire a full picture of whatt he whole data depict. 

So,the data explosion triggers concerns regarding how to handle all the data amassed, while there is a heated debated regarding the amount of data that companies should produce, and collect since lots of them are not exploited and become outdated due to their limited lifespan. Respectively, companies devote lots of money to hold data that may not be useful for its operating activities if they are not exploited in a certain time. Therefore, data explosion may harm the data quality as the managers’ decisions will be based on data that are not accurate and timely anymore. So, while the problem in the previous decades was how to collect data, in our modern economy the problem documents on how to effectively utilize the data received since the warehouse of data does not ensure the good management of them but it can be said that it is only a good start.  

Due to these hurdles, many researchers suggest that some useful ways to deal with such unfavorable situation are to structure a plan in which the data will be arranged properly, to implement real-time processing for interpreting data and to analyze unstructured content.  To do this, Information Technology and Information Management can play a pivotal role in enhancing the data revenues strategy and the business attempt to ameliorate the data quality since optimizing companies’ software and hardware programs,companies will be able to apply more efficient data mining techniques, extracting timely and relevant data and categorizing them. All these benefits lead to better interpreting data that are useful for the organizations’ operation and relatively to the decision-making process. Also, this method helps companies to prevent from confronting with the problem of outdating data given that the collection and the standardization of the data would become in as hort amount of time. As a matter of fact, modern companies should be able to allocate a great number of their budgets in the IT technologies and in hiring people that expertise in this scientific field. 

Once again…. Do not forget that data explosion can be a huge problem in companies’ efficacy and measures should be taken in order to resolve this problem. Take the advantage of Information Technology and see how quick your profits will be increased!

title: Communication investment strategy and marketing communication budgets
description:
A communication investment strategy is one of the most effective methods for companies to attract customers by incorporating both traditional and digital media through the advertisement, promotion and public relations. However, the allocation of a company’s budget to these activities needs a critical examination of the abundance of the factors that affect the interface relationship between the company and the customers to decide how much money companies should devote to each section. 

The traditional media involves tv advertisements, cable TV, radio advertising, print advertising, broadcast, direct mail ads, billboards and off-site signs, cold calling, door-to-door sales while the new media includes the Web, search engineoptimization, pay-per-click advertising, content marketing, social media, emailmarketing, blogs, e-commerce, viral marketing, internet advertising, and brand entertainment, influencing word-of-mouth, and up-and-comers. 

Generally, a marketing communication budget provides a formal process for planning, tracking and measuring the impact of a company’s expenditures on marketing communications activities. For this reason, the advertisement management requires some certain steps that should be followed for preparing an effective communication budget, namely advertising decision making, selection of target audience, determination of advertisement objectives, development of advertisement strategy, evaluation of message copy, selection of media, determination of the budget and measurement of advertising effects to customers. 

So,a well-planned strategy should be drawn so as to minimize the risk factors that can endanger the profitability of the company due to extra unexpected costs and inefficient communication. With the budget communication, the company invests Money anticipating long-term profits, increasing sales, gaining market share and having returns. Thus, the budget should be consistent with the objectives set by the company and the media plan. 

Also, there are some certain factors that the manager should consider to facilitate the budget construction. The external factors involve the testing of the market conditions, the national activities, the global financial situation, the legislation of each country, the competitor’s activities and strategy, the available new and traditional media, the consumer behavior and their preferences among the media. 

Particularly, the market conditions, as well as the nation-governmental activities and the global financial situation should be evaluated because companies must be aware of the dynamic environment that it operates and detect the opportunities and the risk events that may encounter. In fact, the Legal restriction regarding the kinds of advertisement is of primary importance because the infringement of the law can have a series of ramifications for companies in terms of compensation which can injure the image of the company and their communication stream with the customers. So, if a company operates in a country with strict legal rules concerning certain topic-advertisement, it may be advisable to better focus on promotions or public relations instead of the advertisement.  

Also, knowing the marketing strategy of the competitors, companies can gain some important information about the priorities of other companies and tactics used to achieve better communication with its customers. Moreover, the available media, as well as the forecasts of customer preference among them is also precious, given that they permit the company to assign their money in those media that can be more influential to customers if their objectives are to beat the competition raise awareness of its product and brand. Respectively, the internal factors that should be considered are the sales force, size of the company and its financial healthiness, effectiveness of expenditures, the values and the culture of the business, the company’s objectives, and the stage that the product belongs to the PLC.

title: Administrate your company’s culture properly
description:
The factor that determines how attractive a company is for potential employees is the company’s culture. If a culture is overly relaxed, the company can face problems attracting and retaining conservative professionals who may consider the workplace to be inadequately serious and detrimental in the long run for their careers. If the culture is too formal and strict, young and creative employees are likely to feel awkward and out of their water. If women and minorities are not welcome, charismatic individuals belonging to these groups will seek work elsewhere. None of these groups will be willing to work for a company when its culture is dominated by conflicts, persecution, non-functioning top management, or over-privileged hierarchy.

As a first step, to improve the company’s culture, ask your employees the following questions:

1. Are there any significant gaps between the atmosphere in which you would like to work and the atmosphere that characterizes our team today? If so, what are they?

2. What measures would help to improve workplace work and would assist to close the gaps between what we need or want and what we do?

There are many ways to fill the gaps between your company's existing culture and the one you need to attract and retain great people. Here are some indicative scenarios:

1st: The young employees in your department want a much simpler, more enjoyable and dynamic culture. They think that this culture is too formal and rigid. In this case, you could try the following:

·        Relax the clothing code

·        Apply flexible hours which allow employees to work for many hours during the period of the craftwork and fewer hours in other periods.

·        Install a ping pong table or a soccer ball to allow employees tochannel their energy.

·        Go your team to a local park for a volleyball game and a picnic.

·        Start a tradition that you will celebrate with a party to complete difficult projects.

·        Bring funny videos and view them in a meeting room.

2nd: Your department has many employees who have just created a family. They do not like the existing distinction between work and family life. Consider the following ideas:

·        Establish a regular family picnic and encourage employees to even bring their pets. 

·        During informal discussions, ask employees about their families and show real interest in what they are saying to you

·        Allow employees to occasionally bring their children to work to celebrate special occasions.

·        Facilitate work from home during part of the week or provide flexible working hours or other arrangements to reduce employee stress

·        Allow workers to return home early on their birthday or wedding anniversary or to attend parent and teacher meetings or major school events.

3rd: Your team consists of researchers who need isolation and quiet to gather and write as required by their work. Try the following ideas:

·        If your department has cabs instead of door offices, invoke "white noise" machines to drown out the annoying noise

·        Allow employees to work from home in times when they are working on particularly pressing projects.

·        Maintain the frequency and duration of the meetings to a minimum.

It is clear that improving your culture does not have to be difficult or costly. All you need to develop is the right culture and be willing to watch and listen, have a little imagination and be open to new ideas. 

However, keep in mind that directors must produce visible symbols of the culture they intend to promote. Employees look at what top management does. In other words, if you pursue your culture in these ways and really try to change for the better, you can make your company more attractive to employees that you would like to hire and enhance the retention rate of your workforce.

title: The quality management and the exploitation of the human resources
description:
The quality management strategy is a relatively recent phenomenon which is the result of the constant search for a stable competitive advantage in the context of growing market competition. The strategic approach to quality, due to its preventative nature, is considered the most appropriate for the diversification of the services offered, as opposed to the occasional effort to improve the quality that is expressed in response to market needs and therefore is passive.

Critical variables for the success of quality management have identified the time, organizational transformation towards aculture of quality with modern technology. The intensity of quality management activities is considered to affect not only the quality but also the ability ofthe business to respond to the customer's needs in a flexible way.

Quality management, as a universal approach, is based on specific fundamental principles:

• A client orientation that includes both the outside and the interior, as a common goal of the efforts of the whole organization and its members

• Process orientation that enables them to be analyzed in key tasks, as part of the quality chain with specific customers and

• The continuous improvement of products andservices through the use of people in identifying and implementing the appropriate changes.

To improve service quality, companies should:

• Focus on the market and the customers that allow the diagnosis of their needs and expectations and the manifestation ofsuch actions

• Independent responsibility of first-lineworkers that gives them the power to make important customer service decisions

• The existence of properly trained staffwith development opportunities and reward systems and recognition and performance evaluation; and

• The existence of a clear service qualityvision that precludes the arbitrary interpretation of quality service and the inconsistency of its efforts to improve and the variability of the results

Of course, a strong competitive strategy cannot be realized without the existence of stable and competent human resources, as the high dynamism of the markets has made it an important source of competitive advantage.

The human resources capabilities and theircontinuous upgrading and enrichment are a strategic determinant of quality andhigh economic outcomes. The more skilled and knowledgeable the human potentialis, the more appropriate it is to design processes and offer services that bestmeet customer needs.

Proper encouragement and the provision ofdevelopment perspectives are favorable conditions in this direction. The needto continually improve quality and increase productivity often leads companiesalong with their dramatic cost cuts, to reductions in their human resources,which entails additional staffing difficulties for the remaining staff. Qualitymanagement requires a flexible, competent and high commitment to the commonhuman resources objectives.

Finally, technology is referred to as a means oflimiting the complexity of service processes, expanding the possibilities ofoffering services of many different choices, with significant economies ofscale. The use of technology, in addition to the partial substitution of humanlabor (as in the case of ATMs), gives new dimensions to the skills and skillsof workers. It is believed to upgrade their knowledge and enhance thedevelopment of their skills in the services they provide and in customerservice

title: Want to become successful entrepreneur?
description:
To run a business smoothly, the basic requirement is to plan and execute the same in order to attain the desired objectives.

Planning is a process in which there is a need to analyse the environment in order to ascertain the needs of market which ultimately helps business to match the requirements. Planning is one of the very crucial steps that must be superintended while cope up with the requirements which occurs with the dynamic environment.


We can take any businessman as an example to ascertain that how the process of planning helped them to become a successful entrepreneur.


It wasn’t so easy for any entrepreneur to become the successful one without having a plan supported with PLAN-B. We all must have been heard that there must always have a PLAN B in order to avoid the problem of wastage of time. PLAN-B is to be set aside with an assumption that if in case because of any kind of reason PLAN-A fails then the business can continue with another plan.

'PLAN-B plays an important role than PLAN-A'. 

In order to become successful entrepreneur, an individual must follow the business strategy. The first step in business strategy is to plan supported with PLAN-B. The next step is to organise people for different work by dividing the whole task into different small task according to their skills. After organising the third step is directing, which means every employer must guide to the employee that he must complete his task.


The last and most important step is to control the management and analyse the results. The comparison between achieved results with the standard output will disclose what the organisation have achieved and what it may achieve by changing its strategy for the better results.

'The one may become entrepreneur but not successful entrepreneur without having Business Strategy'.

title: The dark side of startup failure
description:
The dark side of startup failure

 Every person in this world have some problems and issues. Some felt it a lot and without facing they just dump their life and some take it in an easy way and face it and they don't even think whether the results will be positive or negative. Some people are depressed from their families, some from their jobs and several other reasons can be listed and such lists can't be end. Now question arises what's the difference between these two types of people. Firstly, the people who are not able to console themselves, feel demotivated all the time, they just start going into the depression and hence they are not affected by their surroundings of what is happening nearby. They just started to be in themselves and hence they may choose the wrong path like drinking alcohols every time and all the day or they start taking drugs like cocaine or the drug injections. As a result, they become addicted to all this and once the availability of all these things gets disrupted, they began to lose their control over their mind and actions and start doing criminal offences for such things or either they can suicide or sometimes time itself ruins their life and such kind of people have no future rather than black life and at end they rest in peace However sometimes it's not the fault of that particular person. Sometimes the society is equally responsible for such instances. In this era, with increasing competition levels, the achievement of success rate requires a lot of hardwork and a lot of hardships. Some people have financial problems and they either take the loans or they just do part time jobs for their dreams to be fulfilled. Ass a result, the loan taking persons fall in debt and started staying in depression. As a result, the people started abusing them and all their confidence level gets loosen and they lost their goals. However government should also help such kind of people so that everyone can achieve their goals and also everyone has the right to life happy and healthy life. On the other hand, the people though belonging to the middle and poor family, being full determined and confident about their goals in future face hardships and it is the person itself only who can give strength and motivation to themselves and achieve their goal. They never listen to what other people say about them and this is the most positive thing which every person should have in his heart and nind. Person should always kept in his mind “Winners never quit and quitters never win.”

title: Finding the Perfect Dropshipping Supplier
description:
The whole dropshipping model will be based with the suppliers doing their job really well and are fulfilling orders efficiently and punctually. Therefore, it goes well without saying that selecting the right suppliers are the most important initial step towards opening a successful brand. When it happens that the supplier messes up your order, your business and you are the one responsible for it, so the key is to look for someone that will stick with the plan and have an open communication when there are issues that will arise in the future of team-up.

Below are some of the factors to bear in mind when selecting the dropshipping supplier:

1. Look for the experienced dropshipper with helpful sales agents. Nothing beats experiences. A dropshipper who is aware of the pitfalls of dropshipping and about how you can handle them effectively, coupled with the sales representative that will answer any queries will surely put your mind and worries at ease, and it will make a really good team-up and will definitely reflect a positive impression on your business.

2. Look for a dropshipper that will provide high quality, top-notch products. The high quality products give way to a high level of consumer satisfaction and that means a lower cost of unsatisfied customers and returned items. Testimonials and product reviews will go a very long way in boosting business, thus, having the best quality products are imperative.

3. Look for a dropshipper that has technological capabilities. When choosing your dropshipper, be sure that they know some technological abilities in keeping up with the time. When you want to scale up your business, it might be a disgrace if you have to break the great business alliance with your dropshipper just so they would not be able to maintain with your growth.

4. Look for the dropshipper who is efficient and punctual with the dropshipping process. Dropshippers that are shipping products within 24-48 hour period is the great way to make sure that the customers are being satisfied and happy. Because of the market’s competitiveness, long shipping times may be unattractive to your customers. This can be advisable to put on your test orders with the suppliers to see how they process their work and to have the best idea before you come up with the final decision of choosing them as your suppliers.

This may sound really simple, but, Google will be a best bet when searching for your future dropship suppliers. Some of the websites and startup incubators dedicated to Ecommerce, which pop up as hunt results, will have the entire directories of Dropshippers with the contact details. The moment you have acquired the contact details for the dropshipping supplier that are providing products you have an interest in selling, then, send them some polite, short email asking a few of your relevant questions. By this way, you will be able to gauge about how rapidly they respond and about how helpful the sales representatives are.

It is not always likely to know whether your suppliers and you will be of perfect fit right off a bat, but, it is likely to ask some questions that can make the vetting procedures more efficient.

Josh King Madrid better known as Jet, is a successful serial entrepreneur, investor, marketing specialist, coach and CEO of Team Jet Set, he specializes in the industries of e-commerce, marketing, business consulting, and fitness.

title: The principles of balancing job and life obligations
description:
The balance between work and personal life is a big issue nowadays. Many people say enough with endless days of work, torn vacations, and nights spent in hotel rooms, and emails that take weekends from their boss. A lot of companies have received the message and responded properly by launching programs that help employees to balance the two sides of their lives. 

Many entrepreneurs consider that any concession made for the purpose of reconciling work and personal life would correspond to significant costs for the companies and a burden to their finances. However, the balance between work and personal life can be modeled through a "win-win" perspective and not through a game with any effects.

Work and personal life are not competitive but complementary priorities. In essence, they have adopted a philosophy that everyone wins. And they appear to be right. The new approach does not bring tangible benefits to both companies and employees individually.

So, if companies want to maintain a good state in their businesses without exhausting their employees but rather keep them happy and pleased, they should read the following advice. 

1. Ensure that employees understand the company's priorities and encourage them to be clear about their personal priorities: The company’s job must be done and the balance between work and personal life must not be an excuse to slip away. Alternatively, work cannot be an excuse to leave important personal slogans to slide. Directors need to be clear about the company's goals and performance. At the same time, they should encourage employees to be clear about their goals as members of a family and as individuals. 

Once all these are done, programs and tasks can usually be customized in ways that meet both sides. The fact that these directors define business success based on the results is definitely essential. For them, the results count more than the process. On this basis, they provide their employees with specific goals but also great autonomy in how to achieve these goals. The combination ofemployees’ autonomy along with the determination of the goals and the expected results is a procedure that helps to be promoted a more flexible schedule for employees’ working hours. 

2. Recognize and support employees as integrated personalities who have important roles outside the workplace: Directors can only handle the conflict of work and personal life if they understand and are interested in the extra-life lives of their employees. The sign of real interest creates a bond and gradually a sense of trust which brings to the company benefits that each manager anticipates.

3. Continually experiment with how employees perform the job: Smart managers know that production processes need to be revised and redesigned periodically for greater efficiency and effectiveness. The balance between work and personal life contains opportunities to experiment with these processes. In the descriptions of directors who have successfully implemented the work-life balance, conflicts between work and personal life priorities can indeed be catalysts for identifying work-related disadvantages that otherwise would be hidden.

These three principles should function as a guideline of each company in order to introduce programs that rejuvenate employees, relax them when needed and make them more productive to their job as they are able to strike a balance between the job and their personal obligations!

title: Make In India
description:
Make in India, a type of Swadeshi Movement covering 25 sectors of the economy, was launched by the Government of India on 25 September 2014 to encourage companies to manufacture their products in India and enthuse with dedicated investments into manufacturing. As a strategy it is the road map to respond to global and local challenges through preparations for a World class manufacturing status & knowledge infrastructure that should create further knowledge for stepping on to global competitiveness.

After the launch, India received investment commitments worth Rs16.40 lakh crore (US$230 billion) and investment inquiries worth Rs1.5 lakh crore (US$21 billion) between September 2014 to February 2016.

As a result, India emerged as the top destination globally in 2015 for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI), surpassing the USA and China , with US$60.1 billion FDI. As per the current policy, 100% Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) is permitted in all 25 sectors, except for Space industry (74%), defence industry (49%) and Media of India (26%). Japan and India had also announced a US$12 billion "Japan-India Make-in-India Special Finance Facility" fund to push investment.

"THE MAKE IN INDIA CAMPAIGN ":-

Make in India was launched on 25 September 2014 with the objective of job creation and skill enhancement in 25 sectors of the economy, and "to transform India into a global design and manufacturing hub". The paradigm 'meant not just rapid growth of manufacturing, but rather to provide for a lead role manufacturing assumes in India's growth process'

1. Ease of Doing Business - India jumped to 77th place out of 190 countries in the world Banks' 2018 Ease of Doing Business Index. India jumped to 100th place out of 190 countries in the World Bank's 2017 Ease of Doing Business Index, from 130th in 2016. In February 2017, the government appointed the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the National Productivity Council "to sensitise actual users and get their feedback on various reform measures".

2. Ongoing Global Campaign - "Zero Defect Zero Effect" slogan was coined by the Prime Minister of India, Narendra Modi , as essence of the Make in India initiative that manages advanced processes, materials and technologies to guide the production mechanism that produces products with no defects with no adverse environmental and ecological effects.

title: Importance Of Communication In Business
description:
The purpose of communication is to effect change, to influence action towards the welfare of the enterprise. Communication is essential because, it integrates the managerial function. Every aspect of manager’s job may it be planning, organizing, staffing, directing and controlling involves communication. Business persons share their business information with employees, suppliers, customers, distributors, Government, banks, insurance companies, etc. This sharing of information regarding business activities and their results is known as business communication. Business communication plays a very important role in the success of any business enterprise. The importance of communication in business is discussed below

1. Provide Information:

 Business communication helps in providing information to the customers regarding the products and services of the business organization. 

2. Quick Decision Making:

 Effective communication facilitates quick-decision making. In today’s world of competition, quick-decisions are necessary. Proper Communication saves times, reduces wastage and cost and induces prompt action. 

3. Effectively Managing Business Affairs:  

Proper communication helps businesspersons in managing the affairs of the business more efficiently. If the right type of information is made available at the right time through proper communication then the management can utilize it in the best possible manner.

4. Handling Grievances:

 In any organization where communication is proper, employees are motivated to work more because their complaints, suggestions and grievances are taken care of properly. 

5. Improved Offerings of Business:

 In every field, technology is continuously changing. Proper communication places a business person in a better position to improve his products, relationship with employers, customers and others. 

6. Achieving Objectives and Implementing Policies: 

Management of an organization is effective only when its communication machinery is effective. The very existence of management depends upon an effective machinery of communication. Effective communication machinery is important because it communicates, and helps in implementing, the policies and objectives of the organization on the one hand, and also helps in understanding the nature and behavior of the people at work. 

7. Correct Interpretation of Messages: 

A message can be interpreted by the recipient according to the image of the communicator in the mind of the recipient. If the image is bad, the version of the message may be distorted and interpreted differently. The bad image can be erased through proper communication from the other side, which is possible only when there is two-way communication in the organization.

 8. Morale of Organizational Members: Thus, creation of organizational systems allowing two-way traffic will improve the morale of the workers on the one hand because they think that they have a say in the management, and will improve the working of the organization on the other hand, because management-worker relations develop in a cordial atmosphere. Thus, two-way communication is necessary for effective management.

title: Franchising In India
description:
Franchising is not a separate form of business organisation but it is the business arrangement and it may be a sole proprietorship or partnership or company. Over the past few years franchise contract is becoming more and more popular. With the growth of service sector the opportunities in India for franchising are going to be multiplied. As per the study by Anderson Consulting, franchising inn India accounts for 4 per cent of the Nation Gross Domestic Product. In US the global franchise economy accounts for 17 per cent of the world’s business. The franchising in India is growing in various sectors like, Food, Healthcare, Education, and Entertainment etc. over and above the traditional franchising business like petrol, auto dealers and soft drink bottles the rapid expanding industries for franchising is training, education, and recreation and leisure activities. The franchising would be catalyst to give a forward push to entrepreneurship.  The word franchising comes from the French word “franchir” which means “to free”. It originally meant “to free from slavery”. Today the franchise is an agreement between a buyer (franchisee) and a seller (franchisor).

          “Franchising is the transfer of rights to sell a trademarked product or service through a system prescribed by a franchisor (seller of right) who owns the trademark. Franchising is a business arrangement in which the owner of a trade mark, trade name, or copy right has licensed others to use it in selling goods or services. It can be sole proprietorship, partnership or company form. Franchise also means expanding the business in the new market by transferring trademark and goodwill to franchisee by charging fees.

                  In general it can be said that Franchise is a local representative of any organization who markets and conducts the entire marketing activity under complete guideline and support of franchisor in the area allotted to the franchisee. It is a kind of authorization granted to an individual or corporation by a franchisor to sell its goods or services in a defined way. Franchise is a system of distribution through which the owner of product approaches independent businessmen in selected territories, appoint them as sole franchisee for particular areas and encourage them to distribute the product within the area assigned. The owner called as franchisor retains control over the technique or style with which the product is merchandised. The franchisees are given certain areas and as per the contract the franchisees are expected to promote the sale in a specific manner. The franchisor provides equipment, gives his brand name, undertakes publicity, provide managerial and technical assistance. The franchisee has to adopt selling techniques and see that maximum sale is promoted through his local network.

title: Allocate your marketing communication budget
description:
The marketing communication budget allocation of any project needs to be determined and selected the media that has the minimum costs with the higher profits and benefits for the company in terms of quick message dissemination and consumer’s attraction. For this reason, quantitative and qualitative media planning should be organized. An appropriate allocation method is to combine both traditional and digital media so as to balance the benefits and the risk of the company’s strategy by developing good communication with the targeted customers. 

The main goal of such an investment is to raise awareness about the product/service benefits, highlights the brand, create a professional image of the company, and inform the customers about the products so as to increase sales. As a matter of fact, the overall available budget should be defined with the propose to be allocated in communication activities based on the above criteria, taking into consideration the budget of previous years so as to measure their usefulness and enhance them with new ad ventures hopefully improving the quality and the efficacy of the communication strategy. 

Traditional media can help to achieve companies’ profitability by increasing sales volume because they transmit messages relating to the particularities of each product, while digital media contributes to ameliorating brand equity and the involvement of customers. 

In particular, digital media is more appropriate to expand product’sspecification, because it offers a strong interaction between the company and customers who are able to give feedback, answer to questionnaires in websites, provide suggestions for product improvement etc. Armed with these tools, digital media can influence the beliefs and the customer’s attitudes about the product and establish a trustworthy relationship between the consumers and the brand. As complementary to the above purposes, the traditional media should also implement at a half percent for customers that are not fond of the Internet. 

Also, the digital media serves to increase brand awareness and company’s image due to the advent of the rapid pace of the technology and a lot of people that they use them. So, for products that belong to the growth or early maturity phase of LPC digital marketing is more preferable as it engages customers into product’s promotion. Besides, through the available online platforms, in which customers can interact with each other and communicate with representatives of the company, the company may achieve a better interface with its customers, as the latter understand that the company try to meet their demands and want to satisfy their needs eventually leading to building strong bonds of trust with the brand.  Moreover, people exchange experiences about the brand, companies start to have funs, followers and thus its reputation is expanded a lot globally. 

Aligned with this, traditional media can have a counter balancing function and companies should invest less money in it so as to be achieved brand visibility for those that are not involved in the digital market. 

Therefore, it is suggested that it should be allocated from $400 to $10,000 to branding, $3,500 to $15,000 in websites, $1,500-$4,000 to social media, $300 per month to $3,000 in ad content, and $250 to $1,000 to events and $500 to $800 in traditional media. In general terms, new companies could allocate 12 to 20 percent of its gross revenue on marketing, while established companies between 6 and 12 percent of their gross revenue. Another interesting approach is to create a  “safe” budget which includes 70% of the budget be allocated to “tried and true” channels, 20% allocated to “safe bets”, and 10% allocated to “experimental”. Undoubtedly, all these values should be examined according to the objectives of the company and the prime areas that they want to focus more

title: Ethical leadership and the businesses’ consequences of lack in ethical leaders
description:
If we want togive a brief description of ethical leaders, we would say that they are people who decide and act on the basis of moral values. Moral leaders have clear values, are fair and honest, have communication skills, are interested in others and are trustworthy. 

Moral leaders as professionals, beyond the key characteristics of leaders, such as the creation of clear vision, motivation, inspiration, they disseminate ethical value to employees, communicate the way decisions are made, keep the promises that they give to employees, they reward the employees’ moral behavior, they scold employees who violate moral standards, they are fair, and they always take ethics into account when making decisions.

Moral leaders honestly exercise their duties and guide and manage employees. Shareholders, employees and other stakeholder groups, such as suppliers and the local community in which the business is active, want and deserve to enjoy a moral response and attitude. 

However, the need for ethical leadership may become more apparent than the analysis of the impact of a company when it is absent. Some of the consequences are as follows:

1. The collapse of corporate culture 

If leaders do not behave in an ethical manner, they lose theircredibility and reputation to the business world. Also, given that an efficient business is based on credibilityand equity, leaders cannot successfully fulfill their roles. As a result of this phenomenon, more and more employees plunge into unethical behavior to the point where practices will become norms. Therefore, the entire corporate culture will collapse.

2. The reduction in the value of the shareholders

Many companies saw the value of their shares collapse as a result of moral problems and their consequences. The role of so-called "golden boys" in precipitating the value of well-known multinational companies and in shaping the gloomy financial crisis is a recenttrend. If leaders are not governed by moral values it is easier to adopt dubious economic and business practices. However, the consequences of disclosing these practices, especially for companies listed on the stock exchange have proved to be disastrous forbusinesses’ sustainability and thus for shareholders’ interest. 

3. The defamation 

The business irresponsibility demonstrated by well-known companies worldwide over the last decades has brought them to court trips and has caused them considerable defamation and harm. It takes twenty years to build the company's reputation and five minutes to be destroyed. As a consequence of this, today, there is a growing tendency for leaders to look beyond the close interest of shareholders, employees, and suppliers. Keep in mind that the general public is a part of a socially responsible behavior of the company which tends to occupy a higher priority in matters of management agenda.

4. The inability to attract talented workers

When it becomes known to the public that a company resorts to unethical practices employees usually are afraid of applying for a job position in these Companies because of their bad reputation to the market. Respectively, talented employees who are aware of their talents aspire to have a brilliant career and therefore, they feel hesitant to be involved in companies that do not inspire trust. Ingeneral, good and talented executives do not like tobe employed in businesses where there are no clear rules and no respect for ethical and moral values

5. The swelling of the regulatory environment 

When businesses experience unethical behavior, the need for amore regulatory environment is growing. This phenomenon makes it hard for allcompanies operating in the economy and resulting in increasing companies’operating costs.

So, the best advice for companies is to try to find leaders that embrace ethical values and are adept at disseminating them to the whole company’s members. In this way, the employees’ morale along with the organization of the company’s structure will be significantly enhanced!

title: Challenges in having diversified employees
description:
Retention is a particularly difficult task when the workforce is highly diversified. And that's the type of workforce that high-ranking executives face in many parts of the world. From age and gender, to part-time and full-time status, ethnicity, race, sexual orientation and physical ability companies benefit from the differences between employees. Uniform strategies for maintaining good staff simply do not work anymore. Companies can improve employee retention rates by formulating creative and specialized strategies for every major part of the workforce.

The members of the temporary workforce, part-time workers, project promoters and temporary workers provide some important advantages, as well as challenging managerial and human resource departments.

The main advantages include:

· Exhibition, as companies can personalize the timetables of these employees to deal with their current workflow and demand by using them only when they are charged.

· Economic capability as businesses employing temporary agents, part-time workers, or freelancers spends money on payroll taxes, health insurance, and other costs.

Challenges include:

· A high degree of renewal that introduces unpredictability and instability into the enterprise culture

· High degree of commitment to the business and its products

· Increasing demand for the same benefits that regular employees enjoy, such as job satisfaction and career development support.

Because the extraordinary workforce is a valuable resource, many companies are currently developing programs specifically designed to maintain these employees.

Also, the younger workers, especially those aged 20 to 30, bring energy, vitality and advanced technology knowledge to the workforce of a business. Young workers are particularly keen to chart their career paths and take up a job that will help them advance to their next jobs.

Nonetheless, many new and young employees are very comfortable with quick changes and flat management structures from their older colleagues. This may create misunderstandings and tensions in the workplace between the two generations, especially when the presbyter and the immediate person come from different expectations of their work.

Many new employees want their employer to determine for them their progress - a career path that will gradually enable them to reach a level of pay that will enable them to maintain their new families. How can your business respond to the needs of newcomers, keeping the best of them?

 You should first understand their background and personalize their work accordingly. Young people know about the contraction in the experience of their parents. They have accepted the reality that sometimes it is not certain in the business world. So, they believe in their own skills. If there is a group for which modifying work or assigning a "tire" project is not just a good but necessary idea, this group is the inactive workers. 

Also, employees that are above 50 years old need attention for two reasons. First, in some companies they represent a good percentage of employees. Secondly, mature workers have extensive knowledge and rich business experience, so they are a big part of the intellectual capital of each company. Many have qualifications, such as credibility, patience or impartial qualifications, acquired only through their daily, multiannual engagement in the performance of their duties.

In order to keep these employees to your company, you may need to create a workplace where the usual practices in terms of job description, hours, earnings, and so on are removed. Remember these tips:

Ask mature workers what their needs are, give them flexibility, make their work more interesting, and adjust the pay system.

Companies cannot scorn the talent they have because they are different from the rest of the people .Every talented employee is valuable and finding ways to stay in the company has business sense.

title: Advertising
description:
• Advertising is a paid form of communication. The advertiser has to pay to the advertising media used for the space or time used to communicate the message to customers.
  • It is a non-personal form of presenting information regarding a product, service or idea because no face - to - face contact is involved between the advertiser and the customers.
  • It is done by an identified sponsor, for example producer or trader. The name or identity of the advertiser is mentioned in the advertisement.
  • It is a form of mass communication. The advertisement can reach to a large number of persons simultaneously.
  • Advertising can be done through a wide variety of media. Such as newspapers, magazines, radio, television, cinema, etc.
  • Advertising is different from publicity. Publicity means any non-paid mention of an enterprise; product or service in the news media. Advertising is paid communication whereas publicity is unpaid. Advertising is sponsored while publicity is not sponsored. In advertising the advertising the advertiser exercises control over the message but in case of publicity control lies with the media. The main object of advertising is to create demand for goods and services whereas the main objective of publicity is to improve public image of the firm.

title: Marketing-based employees’ retention strategies
description:
Marketing-based employees’ retention strategy requires redesigning work personalization, strengthening social ties and hiring people with the least mobility. Linking employees who may leave with the job opportunities that appear within the company is still a clever tool in their quest to preserve them.

Another way is by adopting new salary plans. Those employees consider that remuneration is not a remarkable strategy for retaining staff. Remuneration is important in the sense that you cannot attract or retain the employees you desire if the latter consider their remuneration to be unfair or uncompetitive. Even people who are more interested in their profession and less money are aware of their own as an indication that the company values their connotation and their abilities. If they feel underestimated, they will leave.

However, remuneration is not a credible motive. Incentives often used by employers, including wage increases result in the best possible temporary improvement in performance. It is clear that other strategies are more adept at conservation issues. You must gradually pay out the bonuses you have agreed. For example, bonuses are paid to the new CEO within 5 years. 

Remuneration is of great importance. However, as a matter of keeping staff, it is easier to manage it more easily than corporate culture. Here are some strategies for setting up a proper pay system:

See what salaries your sector offers: You can assign this work to an advisory firm or apply the following economical options:

·        Locate registered adsonline

·        Get in touch with people working in search engines

·        Consult professionalc ouncils

·        Consider Internal Wage Disparities: Ensure that the pay for each job is broadly the same as that for similar jobs across the company.

·        Do not feel surpassed by your competitors: Just make sure that you can meet the most important needs of your employees

Redesigning the job isanother retention strategy. If you can identify those elements that satisfy but also embarrass a worker in a particular position, then you are able to completely remove the unpleasant places and assign them to other people whowill appreciate them. Think about it. What aspects of this work are unhappy with employees?
If we remove the unacceptable seating from that position, we should add something else to consider the position holographic and what is it?
Assuming that someone has to take up the unpredictable tasks which alternatives are there for their handling.
What does it cost more for the company, the redesign of the position or theexisting rate of renewal shown by this workplace?

Companies are almost always trying to match people with jobs. Written job descriptions and workplace scheduling analyze in detail the tasks and the rendered performance by dictating where, when and how the work will be done. The expectation is that people will comply with descriptions of where, when, and how, which inreality can be highly arbitrary.

To understand the power of personalization, study the aspect of the economy for products and services. In this area, competitive markets have led businesses to provide personalized up to a pointof products. Personalization is a powerful tool in any market where demand is less than supply, including the labor market. To personalize a job to meet the needs of both the company and the workers, think about what, where and how thisparticular position.

title: Managing employees who perform poorly in their work
description:
Each company has individuals whose performance varies; while not all employees are capable of promotion. At the top, there are people whose performance is rated A, meaning their contribution is excellent. Those who score B are doing a good job and people with a grade C do a job that is just acceptable. 

The contribution of the groups to the profit increase differs significantly. On average, A-rated managers increase the company's profits. C-rated managers in the same companies did not achieve profits. This raises the question as to where resources should be concentrated on the development of Sigurur career skills, investing in the development of A and B performance individuals are perfectly reasonable. But does it stand with C-rated people? Doyou have to invest in their growth or simply remove them?

Some companies periodically degrade managers with performance C, while others try to make them fall. But most do nothing to deal with the problem. The cost of this indifference is high both from the point of departure of good employees and from the lack of profit growth.
Every C-rated person has a role and hence prevents the progress and evolution of the rest of the people in the company. At the same time, those who perform for C are usually not good nor are they good mentors for others.

Some solutions to combat this problem

·        Recognize people with C score performance. Iti s certain that some of these individuals can substantially improve their performance if they are given the direction and educational support they require. At this point, the types of skills and the quality of training can bring significant results.

·        Make managers responsible for improving or removing people with moderate performance. People with a C performance can run off a company and should therefore be removed into low-level positions where they can be eliminated in A-rated individuals. If they fail to improve on preparing for these new posts, they consider that the interest of the company would be to expel them.

However, investing in people with moderate performance may worth. The only way to learn if such people deserve the attention of the company is by making an estimate of how much a company's performance would improve if it were able to promote a C-rated person to the next highest levels. What would be the cost in relation to the benefits? Are costs less than the benefits? If the cost outweighs the benefits, then the solution is either to move the person to a place where he or she can respond better or ask him/her to leave the company.

An additional tip that I would like to remember is that you should not hurry to your assessment. You should be careful in examining the performance of your company and take the proper decisions that benefit your company and not only the company’s short-term goals. Think big and outside of the box and you will find what to do with your managers’ performance!
